answers.author: Alexandra Iannolo
answers.text:
Hello,
I found some resources that you might find helpful.
This article describes the success of the Water Utilities Department in Garland, Texas using performance based pay.
http://icma.org/en/Article/10746/Skillbased_Pay_Becomes_a_Model_for_Success_Excerpts_from_a_Case_Study_of_the_Water_Utilities_Departm 
This is a sample amendment adding performance based pay to an existing performance policy.
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/302574/Amendment_to_the_Performance_Measurement_Policy 
I also included a case study from Normandy Park, WA on how they implemented a performance based pay system. 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/6757/Breaking_the_StepandCOLA_Cycle 
You can view a similar case study from Maryland Heights, MO.
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/7407/SkillBased_Pay_Maryland_Heights_Missouri_Case_Study 
Below you can see an excerpt from the ICMA report, “Pay for Performance: The Road to Success.”
http://bookstore.icma.org/Pay_for_Performance_The_Road__P1772C35.cfm?UserID=7736924&jsessionid=4e302b6ed10d317ee517 
Ali Iannolo
Knowledge Network Intern
aiannolo@ICMA.org

author: Jeffrey Earlywine
text:
Our county is attempting to migrate toward a performance based pay system. We have realistic expectations and want to take a positive first step forward next year (formal evaluations, some type of rating system that is tied to salary adjustments). I have reviewed a number of performance appraisal/employee evaluation examples and to be honest I find many to be overly sophisticated, perhaps prepared and packaged by consutlants.
Does anyone know of any good examples, designed for local government organizations, that introduce performance as a factor in pay decisions, without being overly complex and academic?
title: County Administrator
